div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7160] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MARCH 29, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
THE WAR
div.p: General Lindevitch is taking measures to cope with the Japanese turning movement.(Havas)
The Japanese are again advancing. They caused the Russian reargaurd to retreat 13 miles to xxx, which is 40 miles to the south of Gutzuling.(Reuter)

It is uderstood that the intention to mobilize on a large scale has been abndoned for the present. Only drafts of sufficient strength to stiffen Linievitch's army will be sent. Te General will pursue Fabian tactics. (Reuter)

div.head: THE JAPANESE LOAN
div.p: The bankers state they are receiving many French subscriptions for the American version of the Japanese loan.(Reuter)

The exterior of the bamks which are issuing the Japanese loan resembles Boxing Day at the theatres. Special police are preserving order. There are long queues of persons outside the banks, the largest being around the Hong Kong and Shanghai office. It is certain that the loan will be heavily oversubscribed.(R)

div.head: ANGLO-JAPANESE ALLIANCE
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph", in taking up the idea of strengthening the alliance between Britain and Japan, says that the suggetion is receiving general approbation in the City. This will especially be the case if the idea enjoys the moral support of America.(Reuter)

div.head: FINLAND
div.p: A systematic constitutional agitation has begun in Finland and is spreading considerably. A demonstration at Abo was attended by 20,000 persons. Crowds are parading the streets waving revolutionary flags; bands are playing national airs.(Reuter)

div.head: CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE
div.p: Five Cardinals have sent M.Loubet a protest in favor of the Concordat.(Havas)

div.head: NEW ITALIAN CABINET
div.p: The Cabinet has been formed with Signor xxxx as President and Signor Tittoni as minister for Foreign Affairs.(Havas)

div.head: RACING
div.p: 1.Sansovino; 2.Catty Crag; 3.Ranger II. 18 ran. Won by a head,neck dividing second and third. Starting Price Betting: 100 to 9 against Sansovino, 11 to 2 against Catty Cray, and 25 to 2 against Ranger II. (R)

div.head: THE TROUBLES OF RUSSIA
div.p: The disturbances begn here on Sunday evening when the town was ignited in five places. The crowd obstructed the work of extinguishing the themes. All the police stations were wrecked and the prisoners liberated the attempt to sack the municipal treasury wa frustrated. (Reuter)

Violent outbreaks are occuring in many parts of the Caucasus both in the town and country. The peasants declare that they can only obtain concessions by force, and they are, therefore, attacking the municipal buildings and the country seats of the nobles. The Government is sending troops into the district. There is a marked recrudescence of unrest throughout Russia, apparently in pursuance of a "mot d'ordre." (Reuter)
Warships and military reinforcements have arrived here. Order has been restored(R)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at the GPO, Alexandria, at 6:30 pm today. The French Ball at Cairo on the 24th ulto. has yielded from 38,000 to 40,000 francs. An Assault at Ams will e given in hte Sulle d'Escrime in the Esbekich Gardens on Saturday next. Ministry of Justice- The report of the Judicial Adviser will be presented t the Council of Ministries before the end of the month. The Reunion Des Families Society are giving their last ball of the winter season on Saturday next, April 1. Masks and costumes will be worn. PWD-Mr. AH Perry, Director-General of towns and Buildings, has completed his annual report, which is to be submitted shortly to Sir Wm. Garstin. Aldersons Garden.- On and from Saturday, 8th April, the variety entertainment in Aldersons Garden Theatre will take place every SAturday at 5pm instead of Fridays. A Ball will be given in Saturday net at the "Club des Princes", Cairo, under the patronage of Miss Gennadis, on behalf of the Greek language propoganda in Thace. Viennese Choral Society.- The members of this society gave a concert at Abdeen Paalace on Monday evening. Yesterday they made an excursion to Sakkara and are gving a concert in Shepheard's Hotel garden this evening. Egyptian Investment- The London Stock Exchange Committee has ordered the undermentioned security to be quoted in the Offiial List:- Egyptian Investment and Agency, 200,000 shares of 1 each, 5s, paid, Nos.1 to 200,000. Suez Canal.- On the 25th and 26th inst. 34 vessels passed through the Canal, the receipts for the two days being frs. 815,022,84. 15 of the ships were British, 2 Italian, 9 Russian, 3 Greek, 5 German. The total receipts from the 1st inst. amounted to frs. 9,087,41299. ALM&DS- At the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute last night, a lecture was given under the auspices of the above society b the Rev. Reginald Rynd, BA, on the "The Natural Use of the Voice". A ggrsat deal of valuable information was conveyed by the lecturer as to the proper mode of developing the vocal organs, and his description of the various reasonant organs of the human frame- in themselves very lucidly described-was rendered still more plain by a large diagram of the head and throat, The importance of the proper management of the resonant organs, nd the way in whic to best avoid the hindrances to good singing, presented by the tongue, throatiness, etc., were fully set forth, and at the close of the lecture the appreciation of the audiece as plainly expressed. A vote of thanks to the reverend lectuer was proposed by Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, KCMG, who presided, and was heartily accorded. We hope that Mr.Rynd wll favor he society with many more of these interesting contributons to the proper understanding of music, nothwithstanding the discouragingly small number of members who turned up last night.

div.head: TERRIBLE ACCIDENT
div.p: A terrible accident occurred at Alexandria yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock, by which three men lost their lives. In Stamboul street, just behind Groppi's establishment, building operations are proceeding, and at the time mentioned the foundations of the house being built gave way, burying three native masons in the debris. Towards evening, the dead bodies of two of the men were recovered, while the other remained buried under a mass of earth and stone. From investigations which we have made, it appears that at a depth of four metres these men were engaged in building up the earth i nthe form of an arch. Th carelessness of native workmen is notorious. It seems that in forming the arch they had taken away some earth on the side of the escarpment. This weakened the layer of earth on top and caused the landslip. Under the circumstances the blame for the unfortunate accident must fall on the victims themselves, as no one but they can tell the stability of their position. Had they been simple workmen, the responsibility would lie with the employers, who should have capable overseers.

The third uhma of the Al Ahzar University, Sheikh Ahmed el Hanbali, has resigned his seat in the council of directors of the University. Two sheikhs only remain, Sheikh Hassanein El Boulaki and Sheikh Hassanein El Edoui. We hear on good authority that candidates for cadi hip will near future, after passing an examination at Al Azhar at an early period of their studies there, go through a special course of training which will be entirely independent of the ancient university

Referring to the announcement which appeared in our columns yesterday, we are informed that the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, will not now be included in the above company, as stated, owing to the fact that the necessary arrangements have not been concluded with the Anglo-American Company. The capital of the new company is 220,000, in shares of 4 each, snd 100,000 in 5% first mortgage debentures. The directors will be Mr. AE Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, (Egypt), Ltd, George Nungovich Bey, Mr. Charles Baehler, and Mr. Pagnon.

We hear that a petition is circulating among the abonnes of the Khedival Opera House (and obtaining numerous signatures), copies of which will be addressed to the Minister of Public Works and to Lord Cromer, Mr Vincent Corbett and Sir William Gastin. The petitiondeals with the decision of the Socitete Artistique to bring an Italian company over in the season 1905-1906, in spite of the decision taken some time ago, and aproved by the Government, to bring French companies over in alternate years. The signatories of the petition complain of this breach of the regulations pointing out that the arrangement previously made enabled good new operas (which by the concession must be produced to the number of four a year) to be brought before the Cairo public. They disclaim all nationalist bias and assert that the plea of the societe Artistique, viz, that a good French company cannot be procured, is utterly untenable. They therefore beg the Minister of Public Works to intervene on behalf of the Government and the public. In our opinion the best way out of the difficulty would be to revoke the concession as soon as possible, and hand over the entire business to a good impressario.. The proverb "Too many cooks" is alarmingly true in Egypt.

Many additions have been made to the menagerie in these gsrdens during the last two months, and one of the prettiest sights now to be seen near Cairo is that of the young gazelles and ibex, of which more than a dozen have recently been born at Ghizeh, playing and frisking about with their mothers in the large paddock which occupies the site of the ruins of the old palace. The births thi spring also include an Arui wild sheep and two Hedjaz sheep, and among the birds, besides numerosu doves of various kinds, two buff-backed egrets have been hatched and reared. Seventeen animals have been presented: an Egyptian weasel by Mrs. Colville, a hawk-eagle by Mr. H. Raczinski of Alexandria, a Nilotic waran-lizard from Luxor by Prof. Dr. G. Schweinfurth, a ring-necked parakeet by Mrs.Bazil, three slender lorises by Mr. J.A. Tarrell, a jungle cat by Mr.AE Branch, seven trumpeter bullfinches and a spotted cuckoo by Mr. GH Malcolm, an a greyheaded love-bird by Mr. S. Hanauer. The purchases during the same period include a yellow baboon, avery larg bonnet-monkey, a white nosed red monkey, some lemurs, two species of wild cat, a Loder's gazelle from the Fayoum, a mouse deer from India, several pretty species of birds not previously represented in the collection, as the lavender finch of Tropical Africa and the Pein nightingale, also two Mina birds, and finally an Algerian tortoise.
By the kind permission of the Inspector General of Prisons, the band of the Ghieh Boys' School will play on Friday afternoons in the gardens throughout this year.

div.head: THE SIRDAR AT SUAKIN
div.p: During his recent visit to Suakin, the Sirdar distributed several robes and other valuable gifts, such as medal dresses, watches, revolvers, knives, and shaving articles, to a large number of sheikhs of tribes, clergy, and faithful guides and attenants for their loyal services these few years to the Government. After this ceremony was over he delivered an eloquent address in English which lasted 45 minutes, and which was then interpreted into Arabic by his Arabic secretar, Shaheen Bey, and afterwards again interpreted into Hadendow by the Commandant of Police, Mohamed Bey Ahmed.

In the evening his Excellency was entertained at dinner at the Moudirieh. Afterwards a reception was held, when Saghcolaghassi Aly Effendy Ahmed,Deputy-Inspector of Suakin Moudirieh, addressed his excellency the Sirdar in English as follows: "Your Excellency,-I have been chosen by the Egyptian officers, officials and employes of the Government of Suakin to stand respectfully before your Excellency and to express their happiness on your visit to this province and town. All the people of whatever station, the richest and the poorest, the highest and the lowest, have taken this oppurtunity to welcome you by their shouts and respond to the consideration and goodwill you have ever shown to all. All whom you find around you are anxious to assure you of their warm feelings and pleasure. The whole Sudan recognises and is grateful for the wise and good administration of the coutnry. The whole Sudan recognises and is ggrateful for the manner in which the happiness and well-being of all classes are considered. Not only the whole Sudan, but the whole world recognises the spledid way in which the country has thriven during the years which you have been Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan, and wonders at the magnificent manner in which the resources of the coutnry are being developed. It is true that during this period all departments of the GOvernment have accomplished much, but in this province we watch perhaps more keenly than others, the miles of railway which are joining the Nile and Red Sea, and the plans for the development of the ports of the Sudan. We know that all that has been the result of your master spirit and encouragement. I am not able to express all that is on my mind, but specially we would thank your Excellency for the honor of your visit to us this evening, and in this way showing that you have a warm heart and kind feelings for all those serving the Government of this country. I ask all who are present to drink the health of his Excellency the Sirdar of the Egyptian Army and the Governor-General of the Sudan, El Ferik Sir Francis Reginald Wingate Pasha." The following congratulatory order was published after the Sirdar's departure:-El Miralai Howard Bey, Mr. Kerr, and the military officers and officials of the Egyptian Army and Sudan Government for their admirable arrangements for his recetion, and for their good and hard work to which the very marked improvement in the condition and progress of the town and province since his last inspection in 1901 is due. "He was much struck with the smartness and turn out of the guard of honor furnished by the 3rd Battalion, and the excelence of the organisation and the careful arrangements made for the treatment of the sick in the military and civil hospitals. The interest taken in education as evinced by the satisfactory state of the school and scholars, was most marked. He also wishes you to convey to El Miralai Macauley Bey his great appreciation of the hard and valuable work done by him and his staff on the new Railway, of which the substantial progress already made is the best testimony. In conclusion he would like to express to you, your officers and officials, and to all classes of people of Suakin, his cordial thanks for the loyal and hearty reception on his arrival and hospitatlity extended to him during his stay." (Signed): LO Stack, Kaimakam, Mil. and Private Secretary.

The following officers have been promoted to the rank of Miralai:- Kaimakams H Matchett Bey, L. Stanton Bey, R Griffith Bay, W Persse Bey, C Blunt Bey, R. Griffith Bey, G. Maucalay Bey, and L Satck Bey. Miralai GP Hunter Bey, DSO., has been appointed Principal Medical Officer of the Egyptian Army.

The Moss liner "Tabor" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning. The SS "Grecian Prince", from Manchester, left Malta on Monday and is due here on Friday next, with passengers and general cargo. The SS Crypian Prince, from Antwerp, left London on Monday last, with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.

The short service held by the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East at 4:45pm on Monday in St. Mark's Church was quite private. It had not been possible to fix the exact hour until the day before, too late t announce it in the "Gazette". The Bishop, who was attended by his acting chaplain, the Rev. Canon Ward, inserted the following special prayers in a shortened form of evening service. "In the faith of Jesus Christ we dedicate this memorial stone, now handed over to the charge of the chaplain and the trustees of St. Marks Church, to the peretual memory of the Csnon Edwin John Davis, MA i nthe church in which he s long ministered. May those who worship here, and face his effigy as they go out from this House of God into the world, hear in memory the example of one of whose loving and charitable labours for the good of Christ's poor, should stimulate the spirit of charity in others; and whose watchful care of the interests of this foundation of St. Mark's has left to his successors great possibilities for happy influence in the chaplaincy which he served for so long a time. "Assist us mercifully, O Lord, in these our supplications and prayers, and in this our act of thy servants towards the attainment of everlasting salvation, that among all the changes and chances of this mortal life we may ever be defended by Thy most gracious and ready help; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen"

At Mansourah the services will be as follows:- April 2, evensong, 6pm; April 9, Litany and HC, 11 am; April 16, evensong, 6pm. Note- Collections on the last Sunday at both chuches (1st after Easter) will be devoted to the SPG. All other offertories and collectioms go to the Delta Itinerating Chaplaincy Fund. J. David C. Firminger, SPG Chaplain

La Delegation Municipale s'est reunie le 28 mars 1905 a 4h. pm sous la presidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli. La Delegation arrete parmi le programme des routes a faire cette annee. Les devis at cahier des charges devront etre presentes au fur et a mesure au College pour la mise en adjucation. Elle adjuge a M. Degiarde la furniture de 60 bancs et 40 chaises pour le jardin Nousha; la route de Ramleh, a M Erriques; enfin la fourniture de balais et couffins, a MM Abdel Rahim Hekel et a M Stamatepoulo. Les offres presentes pour la demolition d'une maison, rue Sinadino, n'ayant pas para satisfaisantes, la Delegation decide de refaire une nouvelle adjucation pour ce travail. La Delegation renvoie au sujet de la construction de la conduite de raccordement pour le deversement des eaux de lavage des nouveaux filtres. Elle proposera a la Commission l'overture d'un credit supplementaire de LE 600 pour le jardin Nouzhe. La seance est le ee a 8h. pm.

Avec la representation de Notre Jeunesse, la compagnie Coquelin Cadet a pu enregistrar une de see crations, et M. Jean Coquelin s'y est autant distingue dans le role de Lucien Briant qu'avanthier dans celui du marquis de La Seigliere Quant a Mme Moreno, elle a su rendre a la perfection deux ou trois soenes pathetiques qui lui ont valune ovation. Nous devons encore une mention particuliere a Mme Bouchetal et a l'heureuse interprete du role de Luoienne Briant qui ont ete toutes deux justement remarquees. M. Coquelin Cadet a termine la representation par trois monologues qu'il a debite d'uue facon exquise. Ce soir Lee Romanesques, comedie en trois actes de M. Edmond Rostand, et L'Ete de la Sanit Martin, comedie en un acte de MM. Meilhac et Halevy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Major General Sir Ronald Lane and Lieutenant General Sir Thomas Kelly Kenny, who have respectively held the positions of Military Secretary and Adjucant General to the British Army, are leaving Egypt on Monday next by the Bibby SS Staffordshire from Port Said Sir Ronald Line is staying with Mr. Gould until tomorrow when he returns for a few days to Cairo.
Yesterday Sir Ronald paid a visit to Victoria College in company with Mr. Gould and was very much pleased with this institution.

The "Journal du Cairo" remarks:- On donne comme probable la nomination de M. Sheldon Amos, juge au Tribunal indigene de re instance du Caire, comme conseiller a la Cour d'appel indigene en remplacement de M. Coghlan.
The Italian man of war "Liguria" is expected to arrive at Alexandria shortly with the Duke of the Abruzzi, who is on his way home after a voyage round the world.

It is not generally known that the credit for the suggestion of England's purchase of the "St. James Gazette", whose 75th birthday is to be celebrated by a banquet in London. When an oppurtunity offered of buying the Suez Canal shares which now form so important a national asset, it was Mr. Greenwood who suggested the purchase to Disareli. Disareli jumped at it, and the thing was done. The statesman got the kudos, but to the journalist belongs the credit.

Egypt has been from the beginning the background for a career of much distinction in the case of Captain Colin Keppel, who has been recently appointed to succeed Sir A Milne in command of His Majesty's yachts. During the attempt to relieve General Gordon, in the subsequent rescue of Sir C. Wilson under Lord Charles Beresford, on the Nile in 1898, when he commanded the flotilla, and at the CB, Captain Keppel won unqualified praise for his ability and courage. As a midshipman be participated in the bombbardment of Alexandria.
Mr JIR Dempster, whose sudden death we annonced yesterday, was chief engineer of the New Egyptian Compsnys Nile reclamation works.
Mr.ALP Weigall has been appointed inspector to the Antiques Service at an annual salary of LE 400.
The Rev. Alf. A. Cooper, MA, of the British and Foreign Bible Society, is expected back in Alexandria on the 1st prox. Mr. Cooper travels by way of Berlin, Vienna, and Constantinople.

The following officers have been granted leave of absence on private affairs:- Capt. S.J.Somerville and 2nd Lieut.CEG Varnon, 2nd Royal Inniskiling Fusiliers; Liet Col. Berks. Regt., Capt.GB Byrne and 2nd Lieut RSW Walpole, 2nd Rifle Brigade; Liet. TC Cunningham, AOD. Major EJ Lawson, AVD.
